elements.text: PART ONE
First, a pre-credits sequence...
SCENE 1.1 —- KALED CITY.
Slow fade up — to a pulsing sound, reminiscent of, but not quite the
same as the ‘electronic heartbeat' Dalek control room noise. This starts
thoughtful, and builds to a rant...

When I press this switch, I will die. The poison in that injector will kill me in a moment. It is a perfect, efficient killing machine. It will be painless, they say. They tell me they know the pain I am in — as if they could! — and that just by pressing this switch, I will end that suffering forever. They say I should be the one to do it. But they are weak. They cannot bring themselves to look at me, let alone kill me. They hesitate. They fear me. Even when I am like this, and they have their perfect, pure, strong bodies, they fear me. And well they should. Iam no longer like them. I am above them. I have the ultimate power — the power of life and death. This body... this is my dominion. Mine to command, no one else's. I can sense them out there in the corridor. Cowering, not daring to speak. They are the frail ones, they are the crippled. They are the ones without choice. They will die. They will lose this war, and they will die. I could join them in defeat and death. But if I survive, then something stronger will emerge, a new race, the supreme power in the universe. I will not press this switch, I will not cower, I will not die! I will not die! This is not the end: this is only the beginning! !
Crash to: opening music.
SCENE 1.2 -SPACE FREIGHTER. Engine noises, electronic bleeping — we're in a spaceship.
Are you stalling for time? Are you?
No... no. It's just that I'm not sure how to open it. We weren't meant to unseal the vault in transit.
Electronic squawk.
(Quiet and distorted, coming in over an earpiece) You're behind schedule.
I'm at the vault door, the pilot can't get it open.
(Quiet and distort) So there's a problem?
There are no such things as problems, my dear, just potential solutions.
—= (Quiet and distort) How do you suggest we solve this potential solution, darling?
Well — I could kill the pilot and find another member of the crew that can open the door.
The PILOT yelps.
But I've tried that a couple of times already and the ship only had a crew of three. need you to come over.
—= (Quiet and distort) I thought I was staying over here to watch out for patrol ships.
Change of plan. Set the computer for automatic scan and bring me my blue holdall.
(Quiet and distort) I'm already in the docking tube.
Look — I know this freighter is registered to the Galactic Bank, but the cargo isn't money, or bonds or anything it's just a
SFX: Door hisses open.
Here.
SFX: Unfastening the holdall.
I didn't want to use explosives — we'll set the alarm beacon off. But we don't have any choice. Attach this to the locking mechanism.
We hear clamping sounds thunking against the metal door. SFX: Small bang... then a heavy door whooshes open.
__ It worked!
Careful, the vault may be booby-trapped.
The voices echo now they're in a small vault.
__ No, they didn't think anyone could get this far. That's why there are no lights. Have you got a torch?
Here. (Beat, then a grunt of surprise.)
I told you there was no treasure. Just that. A dead body.
That's what separates people like us from people like
you, pilot. You and the rest of the herd would look at this and see... nothing. We see an opportunity.
You do know who this is?
Yes... it's — (hesitates)
_ Hecan't even say the name. It's Davros, pilot. This is the body of Davros.
It doesn't matter who it was. He's no use to you dead.
SFX: Small buzzing alarm.
__ A patrol ship just came into range. It's altering course and heading this way.
We have to get moving. The body's light enough, I can move it on my own. I'll get it back to our ship.
~— Wait! Don't take him out of his chair.
He'll be a lot easier to move if I do.
Don't!
All right.
_ When the patrol gets here, they'll be expecting to find a body in the vault — let's not disappoint them.
Good point.
Wait, what are you doing? I could come with you. I... Abruptly cut off by a gunshot. Gut to:
SCENE 1.3 - PEACEFUL WOODLAND. Slow fade-up to: birdsong, we're in woodland, and we hear trudging feet.
Here.
We wait here? How long for? Willis, there could be patrols.
This far from the Dome. Is that earpiece of yours even working?
KIM The signal faded out about half an hour ago.
There you are, then.
You know for sure that there are no patrols?
I’ve got level one access, remember?
You have a press pass. It's not the same thing.
Look around — there's no one here. No one for miles
Including your friend. How is he supposed to land
here anyway? There's not a clearing big enough. Look — he'll have been picked up by a patrol. They probably intercepted him the moment he
entered the system. We have to get back before —
Boo! WILLIS and KIM jump out of their skins.
Hell, Doctor, you frightened the life out of me. You're not due for another half an hour.
I... overestimated how long it would take the
TARDIS to get there. So I've been waiting around here for the best part of the morning.
But the TARDIS is a time machine surely you ought to be able to —
Yes, yes. Now — if I can sneak up on you then those guards young...
Kim. Hello Kim, I'm the Doctor. Well, those guards
young Kim was worrying about could sneak up on us. So, rather than criticise my driving, perhaps we should all get to a safe place, and then you can tell me why you sent me that message.
Cut to:
SCENE 1.4 -—- BAYNES'S INTERCEPTOR.
SFX: Different ship noises and electronic bleeping to Scene 1.2.
We've just entered home system. Dome control has switched us to automatic control for landing.
~— What about that patrol ship?
It didn't even see us. We're well out of its detector range, now.
I'm not sure it matters.
BAYNES Of course it matters.
_ The medical computers on this ship are some of the most sensitive instruments available.
I know — I sell them, remember?
_ But I'm the one with a degree in space medicine. I'm the one that understands what their read-outs are telling me.
And?
LORRAINE And they're telling me that Davros is dead.
A pause.
Dead?
__ Look at him. He's dead. No respiration no cardiovascular activity, no brain activity.
Then there's no hope?
_ This computer is good, but the facilities back home are far better. There could be a chance. We should never give up.
I know. But if he's dead, what can we do?
SCENE 1.5 — KALED CITY.

Slow fade-up — to the ‘electronic heartbeat '. (This — and other flashbacks in this episode — are slightly distorted, echoey. DAVROS's life is flashing in front of him. He's clinging to life, and is delirious. In this scene the Kaled sounds a little like BAYNES — DAVROS's memories and his actual surroundings are blurred.)

We can keep him alive. Kaled medical technology will sustain him for — well, at least as long as his natural life expectancy. He could very well become the first of our people for ten generations to die of old age. But should we? Have we the right? Look at it... him. Look at him.
I can hear you.
Davros. I... the sedatives weren't supposed to...
You are talking to the Elite? They are here?
There is a radio link to the Council Chamber. DAVROS And you are meeting to decide my fate.
Davros, you are one of our greatest scientists, you —
I am the greatest scientist. The greatest mind Skaro has ever known!
No one doubts that, Davros. But the attack...
What has been decided?
You know the principles that built and sustained the
Kaled Nation. Physical strength. Self-reliance. Genetic purity. And you know... you know what you have become.
DAVROS The Elite have voted to have me destroyed.
We... the Kaled people owe you a great debt, Davros.
Tell me what has been decided.
None of us can do it. If Davros is to die, it must be by
his own hand. Here. It's a poison injector, it activates when you flick this switch. It will be painless.
Thank you. You have been most generous.
I... I'll wait outside. For an hour. Thank you Davros, for all you have done. Cut to:
SCENE 1.6 —- PEACEFUL WOODLAND.
We can rest here. And you can tell me what's going
on.
TAI are planning to close all the mines.
TAI?
TransAlliedInc. One of the largest corporations in the galaxy. They have nearly twelve billion employees.
They must have the largest staff canteen in the universe.
(Deadly serious) The workforce is spread over a hundred worlds, Doctor. But that Dome is their headquarters.
Dome? Oh yes. Impressive. However did I miss that? It must be a mile high.
Two and a half, and there are as many level underground even before you reach the mines.
KIM The Dome contains everything they need to run TAI — computers, communications, marketing, training facilities...
WILLIS And in there, the decision has been made to close every mining colony.
Well... it's a human tragedy. But mass redundancy, labour relations... it's really not my field.
It's the fate of twelve billion people. Whole
communities — whole planets — will be devastated for generations. You must be able to do something.
Well... what reason did they give for closing them?
They haven't made the announcement yet.
Then how — ?
I work in the computer section. I discovered secret
files, something from a focus group that someone forgot to erase. I've only told Willis — if the company knew I'd been speaking to a journalist —and he said we should contact you.
I reported on that business on Stellastora, Doctor, I
know what you did there. But I don't just want to file a report on this — I want someone to stop it.
Well, I'll see what I can do. Okay... let's think: are the mines profitable?
Almost every one of them is, yes. There are only a handful that couldn't be run at a profit, if they invested in them, or replaced the local manager with someone better.
It makes no sense.
No it doesn't. (Beat) Can you hear that?
It's a ship!
SFX: We can hear it descending.
It's coming in to land.
It'll be heading for the Dome. That's ten miles away.
It's going to land a lot closer than that. Down!
SFX: Retro rockets are firing right overhead.
There's nowhere to land around here, it's going to —
SFX: The ground opens up. Great grinding noise as hangar doors open.
WILLIS The ground's opening up.
SFX: The ship is descending, almost drowning them out.
There's a concealed hangar. You didn't know about this?
No.
Doctor, where are you going?
If it closes up we might never find our way in. Hurry! Cut to:
SCENE 1.7 - BAYNES'S INTERCEPTOR.
SFX: Same descent noise, but muffled — we're inside the ship itself.
Hangar control, we're inside. Shutting down engines.
SFX: The engine noises gradually die down.
Seal the hangar. Medical team to docking port.
SFX: The hangar doors grind closed.
— Opening airlock. Where is that medical crew?
SFX: Hatch hisses open.
I'll find them. Stay here with the... the patient. We hear him leave.
_ Don't worry, Davros. I'll keep you safe.
SCENE 1.8 - HANGAR.
SFX: We can hear the engines wind down.
I don't recognise the design, but it's human technology.
It's a medium-range interceptor. Built for speed. It’ heavily armed.
I can see that — but no armour or defences to speak of.
Something you'd use for a quick raid, then an even quicker getaway.
Why would pirates operate right under the noses of
the TAI headquarters?
SFX: The ship's hatch hisses open.
Quick! Behind here!
Ow!
Shush!
(Urgent whisper) You stood on his foot.
Will you two be quiet?
SFX: Marching feet — four men in jackboots, pushing a trolley.
Bring that over here. Quick march!
I don't —
Shush! (Whispering) Kim, what do you see?
That's Baynes.
Baynes?
Arnold Baynes, the chief executive of TAI.
My boss. He's one of the richest men in this half of the galaxy.
DOCTOR An unlikely pirate. Who's he with?
Baynes's wife is there, too. They've got an injured
man... no... God... it's horrible.
Don't raise your voice
It's a body. A mutilated body.
Let me have a look. (Beat, then a yell) DAVROS!
Oh, no...
You there! You there! Do you have any idea who this is? Yes, you!
The DOCTOR's heading away from us, towards BAYNES — he carries
on speaking over this.
Quick, Kim: follow me.
What about the Doctor?
He can look after himself.
(Continued, getting closer to BAYNES — and us — again) What are you trying to do?
What the — ? Hold your fire, men! (To LORRAINE)
Get our guest to the medical centre. I'll deal with this.
_ Iwill.
SFX: Door slams shut — we can hear the DOCTOR and BAYNES
arguing, but it's muffled. We're on the other side of the door.
No wonder you're keeping this secret — who else know Davros is here?
Who are you?
This side of the door.
_ It's allright. You're safe. You're safe.
SCENE 1.9 —- KALED CITY.
(Distorted) Davros. Davros, can you hear me?
That smell... I can smell...
Don't exert yourself.
What is wrong with my voice?
Your larynx was damaged in the attack. We've replaced it.
I remember the attack. I remember the explosion. KALED A Thal shell, packed with radioactive isotopes.
I raised my hands to shield myself from the blast. A
foolish instinct. And the light was so intense I saw the bones of my hands. And as the explosion hit me, I flexed my fingers just to see my skeleton moving. What is that smell? I feel... I don't...
We've given you the most powerful sedatives we have Davros.
I don't think they are working. What is that smell?
It's your skin.
My... skin...?
You were badly burned. You were lucky to survive.
No one else in that section did, and...
No... one?
No.
Show me my face.
That wouldn't be...
Show me! Show me!
Davros, you're in the best hands, now, the most skilled Kaled doctors are tending to you, and —
You will show me!
Very well. Here.
I can't see. Move it down. Yes... I... no! No! No!!!!!
screams. Merge with:
SCENE 1.10 - HANGAR.
I won't ask again: who are you?
I'm the Doctor.
Your real name.
Oh, it doesn't matter. Do you know who that is you've brought here?
Tell me.
That is Davros. You know who Davros is? What he's done?
My wife is one of the... no, actually she is the foremost on the subject.
If she knows Davros, then she knows that he is one of the... no, actually he is the most evil being this galaxy has created.
Are you always this melodramatic?
Where Davros is concerned, it's no exaggeration to say —
How did you know that Davros would be coming here?
I... I didn't.
You just happened to arrive here at the precise moment Davros came off the ship?
Mr Baynes. Wait. Baynes. So your wife is Professor L. R. S. Baynes? Teaches history at Dawkins College, Oxford?
She's Professor Lorraine Baynes, yes. She's never
taught at Oxford, though.
Not yet. But she wrote Dalek Genius and The Dark Side of Skaro?
You seem remarkably well informed. You've read them, I take it?

I started them. The idea of reading two rather turgid volumes written by an apologist for the Daleks stuck in my craw. BAYNES The last person to make that sort of accusation lost a lot of money in the libel courts.
He was also speaking the truth. So, you're working with the Daleks, are you? Where are they, then?
No, we are not! The Daleks haven't been active in this arm of the galaxy for a century. The last Dalek War saw to that.
Yet Davros is here.
Davros is dead.
No.
What you saw was a corpse.
Don't underestimate him. You're playing with fire. Where did you find him?
Doctor, you're wasting my time. You're obviously lying.
I never lie, Mr Baynes. I'll ask you again — how did you find Davros?
You're convinced he's alive. So's my wife. Do you think you could resuscitate him?
DOCTOR Of course I could, I'm not some bumbling local quack who —
The DOCTOR realises he's said too much.
How? How would you bring him back?
I'm not saying.
I thought doctors were meant to preserve life, any life.
It doesn't matter who he is, he's a patient in need of care.
What you have at the moment is a corpse.
You can change that.
If you know anything about that monster you've got in there, you know that given the chance he'd kill countless millions.
If you really can revive him, we can make it worth your while.
‘Worth my while’? This isn't about money. And if
Davros is dead there's no moral dilemma here, no life to save: he stays dead, and good riddance.
Come with me.
Cut to:
SCENE 1.11 - CORRIDOR.
Where are we going?
I don't know.
KIM The hangar doors are closed. There may not be another way out.
There must be. What's going on here?
I've no idea.
You work in the computer section of the Dome. You must have had some clue this existed.
None of us ever leave the Dome. It's so large, there's no reason to.
We've no idea how big this place is.
Your friend was no help at all.
WILLIS The Doctor found the hangar. I think he found me a story.
Is that all you care about?
No. Of course not. For one thing, I care about getting out of here alive.
If I don't get back soon, I'll be missed. My work shift starts at two point five.
I'll get you back.
How?
Well, I'm not sure about that bit, yet.
Cut to:
SCENE 1. 12 - MEDICAL CENTRE.
SFX: Medical thingies beep and whirr away.
Can you hear me? (Beat) You're magnificent Davros. Everything I imagined. I've seen images, but they just aren't the same... even with you like this. We'll bring you back. I promise.
SFX: Door opens.
BAYNES In there.
You've brought him here?
He says he's a doctor, and he can revive Davros.
I'm not going to. Look at him. He even looks evil.

— Youare bringing your own cultural biases into play here. You've been told he's evil, so he looks evil. That's what you were told at school, on the news channels — you can't be blamed for that — you've been conditioned into thinking that Davros and evil are
synonymous.
Trust me, that isn't it.
He looks dead to me.
_ Heis. I'msorry...
What? But these instruments — (He shuts up)
What about them?
Check.
_ There was nothing. Wait. The sensors are registering something. There is brain activity. Look.
What am I looking at?
Signs of life.
That doesn't even qualify as a glimmer. That amount of cerebral activity isn't anywhere near a legal definition of life.
Then it's one more law that Davros has broken. He's
alive. And do you know what's keeping him alive?

_ The chair. It was built by Davros himself — a magnificent achievement. It acts as an iron lung, a pacemaker for his heart, it performs dialysis. It monitors his body, coordinates the self- repair circuits.
It's not the chair.
Cut to:
SCENE 1.13 —- KALED RUINS. Murky DAVROS POV scene, same heartbeat. SFX: Rubble shifts, then clatters down and we hear someone scrabbling around.
WOMAN © (In radiation suit, so muffled) 'm through! Oh...
(Very distorted) What can you see?
WOMAN __ Nothing. Dust. Wait.
SFX: Geiger counter buzzes furiously.
WOMAN The radiation levels are off the scale.
Very distorted) Your suit will protect you.
WOMAN _ Not for long.
I'm through. Ah! I've just stepped in —
WOMAN _ What?
It doesn't matter.
WOMAN _ Look up — you can see the stars. We're thirty levels below ground here.
KALED The Thals must have scored a direct hit. At least ten megatons.
WOMAN __ Twelve, probably, or there would be more debris.
Here's Tral Mekta. And that's Chief Scientist Rontral.
WOMAN _ Cal Vergant. At least that's what the name badge says. And... here's Coordinator Davros. What's left of him.
Gods... there's not much, is there?
WOMAN _ They're all dead.
We knew that.
SFX: Alarm buzzes.
WOMAN _ There aren't any survivors.
No. And our suits won't last much longer.
(Very, very weak — and no electronic effect , true voice of DAVROS) Shan?
WOMAN _ Did you say something?
No.
Shan?
It's Davros.
WOMAN _ Butit can't be.
Help me move him.
Where is Shan?
What's he saying? Shan? Is that a woman's name?
Davros, there are no women in here. Even if there were, everyone here is dead.
(Under previous line) Get a medic. Fetch a —
Cut to:
SCENE 1.14 -MEDICAL CENTRE.
If it isn't the chair, then what — ?
Hatred, Mr Baynes. All-consuming hatred of everything that isn't like him.
Davros is unique.
Exactly. Look, whatever you've got planned here you have to stop it. Just allow him to lapse back into suspended animation. Leave him.
~~ Whoare you?
I am the —
Doctor!
There's as long a pause as we can get away with.
Davros.
is catching his breath for the first time in decades, rasping — but it's too much: DAVROS screams.
— Quick, prepare sedatives, we need to stabilise him. Get me ten ccs of dexpanthenol and —
No. No sedatives.
_ The pain...
You think Iam unused to pain? Look at me!
This is incredible. His heart just started, all by itself. Breathing normal. Brain activity approaching normal.
Stop it! You have to —
Get away from him.
Doctor?
The DOCTOR and DAVROS are face to face, BAYNES and LORRAINE are further away.
__Life signs are strengthening, but still nominal.
Are you going to kill me, Doctor? You'll never get a better chance.
Shut him down. End this now.
You are weak. There's the switch. End my life. You,
not them. Do your own dirty work. End my life if you have the stomach for it.
__ Life signs nominal. He's stabilising.
cackles. Cut to:
SCENE 1.15 —- CORRIDOR.
Did you recognise the name the Doctor shouted?
When he saw that body? Davros?
Yes. You've never heard it?
No. Should I?
You've heard of the Daleks. Davros is their creator. But he’s been dead for over a century.
He looked it. Why would they bring him here?
That's quite a relic. There's quite a market for it, isn't there?
For what?
Dalek regalia. My grandfather served in the Dalek
Wars, and I had a fragment of casing he kept on the wall. It took his whole squad to destroy it, they all took a bit home. When he died, it was sold to collector for a small fortune.
For a scrap of metal?
Yeah. So imagine what the body of Davros would fetch.
People would pay money for a dead body?
Oh yes. It's illegal, of course. But that's all Baynes stands for — money.
It's immoral. It's... horrible. (Beat) Wait.
What?
KIM The air. It's changed.
What do you mean? Yes... you're right. There's a breeze.
We've gone down a few levels, haven't we?
Down a few, up a few. I think we're lower now than that hangar bay. I think there's machinery. Can you hear that?
This way.
SFX: Gradually, the sound of a massive clattering machine fades up
over the next bit — it's still quite quiet at the end.
Definitely machinery.
I think you're right.
Through here?
Why not?
SFX: As Willis opens the door, the sound of machinery becomes almost
deafening.
It's a production line.
KIM A big one. Fully automated.
They take it in for a moment.
What's it for, do you think?
Some sort of heavy machinery. I think that's going to be a hydraulic arm.
It's a robot... they're building an army of robots!
Cut to:
SCENE 1.16 - MEDICAL CENTRE.
Who are you?
I'm Arnold Baynes, this is my wife Lorraine.
Davros, it is a great honour.
Who do you work for?
I don't work for people. People work for me. I'm the owner and chief executive of TAI, TransAlliedInc.
A... businessman?
Precisely. And I have a business proposition for you. I want you to work for me.
For you?
Mr Baynes, this is madness.
You'd have the whole R&D department of TAI to use.
You'd be able to green-light projects, you'd have a helicopter view of the whole company and you'll be able to go any blue-skies initiatives you want.
Your words make no sense. Have you resurrected me just to gibber at me?
I can make you rich, Davros.
Rich?
If you worked for me, the sky would be the limit.
I do not understand what is being offered — or expected of me.
BAYNES The human race has come to dominate this galaxy.
We’ve colonised sixty per cent of the habitable worlds and we're within a century of taking the rest. After that... what?
There are other galaxies.
It takes an incredible technology to cross a galaxy but to travel between galaxies is a whole different order of problem.

Exactly. And human technology, as it stands, just isn't up to it. And we humans consume, we expand — the galaxy is a big place, but we'll exhaust, 1t Within a matter of generations. But colonising other galax les — we’d need much better computers just to begin planning that.
DAVROS And you require my help? Why should I assist you?
Well, I'll introduce you to TAI, and you'll see we're on the level. I think the best thing to do first is play this.
Perhaps overlapping with next line to emphasise it's a recording. There's some uplifting music under this.

(V.O. in best voiceover voice) — TransAlliedInc is a good old-fashioned family mega-corporation. Started back in the thirty- eighth century by Elias Baynes as a simple robot manufacturers TAI has gradually expanded by giving its customers what they want — which isn't as easy as it sounds in today's diverse galactic marketplace. Our secret is to anticipate demand, to be at the forefront of innovation and invention. TAI's proud boast is that it can supply any of its products to any planet in the galaxy. And things have marched on since those humble beginnings: we still sell robots, the best on the market but we also sell (brief pause and 'ping' before each one) starships terraformers, medical equipment, explosives, foodstuffs, protective clothing, weft engines, computer brains, recreational narcotics, laser cannons. And that’s much more... Everything a colony world could possibly want to go from this... (howling winds and screams) to this (laughter and birdsong). And that's what we strive to do at TransAlliedInc: build a better world on every world in the galaxy.
There's a swell of inspirational closing music.
_ So what do you think?
Typical corporate claptrap. What you carefully neglect to mention —
Be quiet, Doctor. Davros?
(Thoughtful) A better world... yes, I can see that.
Subversives like the Doctor might complain about
capitalism and universalisation, but that's what we're all here for: to improve the quality of people's lives. To make people feel happy, and secure.
Yes. So Isaw. You'll forgive me, Mr Baynes. On my world... on Skaro there was nothing like this.
It's propaganda, Davros. And there was plenty of that of that on Skaro. It's what they want you to think, it's not the reality.
No. Of course not. I see that. But... it is an ideal. You heard what it said. They strive to do it, they know they aren't there yet.
We could get a lot closer if we had a man of destiny like you working with us, Davros.
It was an advert. Don't tell me that the creator of the
Daleks watches one short film showing happy smiling children running through a cornfield and suddenly the scales fall from his eyes? Baynes, you can't possibly believe that?
Believe. Mr Baynes, we have a deal.
Wait. I have a counter-offer.
You do?
There is a man who can help you, without any of the
risks. Davros isn't the only genius, you know. If you really want to help the people of the galaxy, then — well, you don't need Davros.
So who do you suggest instead?
Ah, well far be it for me to say, but —

— We had the top headhunters in the galaxy looking for the most radical intellect, the greatest mind. They named Davros number one, by a clear margin. It took us a lot of time and money, but we got the best.
Ahem.
So, go on, who is this other ‘genius’?
DAVROS The Doctor is offering his own services.
chuckles.
Do not underestimate this man, Baynes. He is a scientist, he is devious.
DOCTOR And every time we've met, I've got the better of you.

— Oh, you're that Doctor. Well, if I remember my researches correctly — and I do, Doctor — according to all the records, your presence was incidental, at best. The Daleks repeatedly betrayed Davros, or failed him.
Call yourself an historian? It wasn't like that at all! I beat him fair and square. Numerous times.
He is a dangerous opponent. (Grudgingly) He is my
equal.
Iam? I mean: yes, Iam.
Here's a question for you, then: what would you do in my position?
Davros mustn't be allowed even a foothold of power,
ever again. He should be returned to suspended animation. I can give you so pointers with any problem you have.
Davros?

BAYNES: You'd be able to green-light projects, you'd have a helicopter view of the whole company and you'll be able to go any blue-skies initiatives you want.
DAVROS: Your words make no sense. Have you resurrected me just to gibber at me?
BAYNES: I can make you rich, Davros.
DAVROS: Rich?
BAYNES: If you worked for me, the sky would be the limit.
DAVROS: I do not understand what is being offered — or expected of me.
DAVROS: BAYNES The human race has come to dominate this galaxy.
DAVROS: We’ve colonised sixty per cent of the habitable worlds and we're within a century of taking the rest. After that... what?
DAVROS: There are other galaxies.
DOCTOR: It takes an incredible technology to cross a galaxy but to travel between galaxies is a whole different order of problem.
BAYNES: Exactly. And human technology, as it stands, just isn't up to it. And we humans consume, we expand — the galaxy is a big place, but we'll exhaust, 1t Within a matter of generations. But colonising other galax les — we’d need much better computers just to begin planning that.
BAYNES: DAVROS And you require my help? Why should I assist you?
BAYNES: Well, I'll introduce you to TAI, and you'll see we're on the level. I think the best thing to do first is play this.
BAYNES: Perhaps overlapping with next line to emphasise it's a recording. There's some uplifting music under this.
BAYNES: (V.O. in best voiceover voice) — TransAlliedInc is a good old-fashioned family mega-corporation. Started back in the thirty- eighth century by Elias Baynes as a simple robot manufacturers TAI has gradually expanded by giving its customers what they want — which isn't as easy as it sounds in today's diverse galactic marketplace. Our secret is to anticipate demand, to be at the forefront of innovation and invention. TAI's proud boast is that it can supply any of its products to any planet in the galaxy. And things have marched on since those humble beginnings: we still sell robots, the best on the market but we also sell (brief pause and 'ping' before each one) starships terraformers, medical equipment, explosives, foodstuffs, protective clothing, weft engines, computer brains, recreational narcotics, laser cannons. And that’s much more... Everything a colony world could possibly want to go from this... (howling winds and screams) to this (laughter and birdsong). And that's what we strive to do at TransAlliedInc: build a better world on every world in the galaxy.
BAYNES: There's a swell of inspirational closing music.
LORRAINE: _ So what do you think?
DOCTOR: Typical corporate claptrap. What you carefully neglect to mention —
BAYNES: Be quiet, Doctor. Davros?
DAVROS: (Thoughtful) A better world... yes, I can see that.
BAYNES: Subversives like the Doctor might complain about
BAYNES: capitalism and universalisation, but that's what we're all here for: to improve the quality of people's lives. To make people feel happy, and secure.
DAVROS: Yes. So Isaw. You'll forgive me, Mr Baynes. On my world... on Skaro there was nothing like this.
DOCTOR: It's propaganda, Davros. And there was plenty of that of that on Skaro. It's what they want you to think, it's not the reality.
DAVROS: No. Of course not. I see that. But... it is an ideal. You heard what it said. They strive to do it, they know they aren't there yet.
BAYNES: We could get a lot closer if we had a man of destiny like you working with us, Davros.
DOCTOR: It was an advert. Don't tell me that the creator of the
DOCTOR: Daleks watches one short film showing happy smiling children running through a cornfield and suddenly the scales fall from his eyes? Baynes, you can't possibly believe that?
DAVROS: Believe. Mr Baynes, we have a deal.
DOCTOR: Wait. I have a counter-offer.
BAYNES: You do?
DOCTOR: There is a man who can help you, without any of the
DOCTOR: risks. Davros isn't the only genius, you know. If you really want to help the people of the galaxy, then — well, you don't need Davros.
BAYNES: So who do you suggest instead?
DOCTOR: Ah, well far be it for me to say, but —
LORRAINE: — We had the top headhunters in the galaxy looking for the most radical intellect, the greatest mind. They named Davros number one, by a clear margin. It took us a lot of time and money, but we got the best.
DOCTOR: Ahem.
BAYNES: So, go on, who is this other ‘genius’?
BAYNES: DAVROS The Doctor is offering his own services.
BAYNES: chuckles.
DAVROS: Do not underestimate this man, Baynes. He is a scientist, he is devious.
DAVROS: DOCTOR And every time we've met, I've got the better of you.
LORRAINE: — Oh, you're that Doctor. Well, if I remember my researches correctly — and I do, Doctor — according to all the records, your presence was incidental, at best. The Daleks repeatedly betrayed Davros, or failed him.
DOCTOR: Call yourself an historian? It wasn't like that at all! I beat him fair and square. Numerous times.
DAVROS: He is a dangerous opponent. (Grudgingly) He is my
DAVROS: equal.
DOCTOR: Iam? I mean: yes, Iam.
BAYNES: Here's a question for you, then: what would you do in my position?
DOCTOR: Davros mustn't be allowed even a foothold of power,
DOCTOR: ever again. He should be returned to suspended animation. I can give you so pointers with any problem you have.
BAYNES: Davros?
DAVROS: (Rants a little) The Doctor is a known saboteur. He is our enemy. He must be (checks himself before her says 'exterminated') incarcerated.
DOCTOR: Mask slipping, Davros?
DOCTOR: BAYNES The solution is obvious.
DOCTOR: Is it?
BAYNES: You are both men of science. You have a lot in
BAYNES: common. Either one of you would be a perfect addition to our team here at TAI. But why choose? You can work together!
BAYNES: DOCTOR and DAVROS No!
BAYNES: Together, you're going to build a better world.
BAYNES: End of Part One

elements.text: PART TWO
SCENE 2.1 - BEDROOM.
SFX: Alarm rings.

...shot up by over fifteen per cent on news that the corporation's research and development arm has hired galaxy-famous scientist Davros, controversial creator of the Daleks, and his long-time rival, the Gallifreyan inventor usually known as 'the Doctor’, for work on unspecified technological projects which company president and chief executive Arnold Baynes claims will put TAI a generation ahead of the competition.
The DOCTOR wakes up.
Whuh. Uh. Who are you? For that matter, where are you?
I am your personal organiser. I was inserted into your Inner ear while you slept.
Were you indeed?

I will provide you with all the information you need, from financial news to nutrition and fashion advice. It's time to get up, Doctor. It is nine point zero. You are due at work at nine point five, in thirty minutes.
Uh?
You've been asleep for over eleven point five hours.
Wake me at nine point four one six recurring.
I... you will need time to prepare for work, Doctor. (Beat) Doctor?
(Snores)
Fade to:
SCENE 2.2 - BEDROOM/DOME/WORKSHOP.
Fade up DOCTOR snoring.
You are due at work in five minutes, Doctor
(Instantly awake) There we go. Nothing like a lie-in.
What would you like to have dispensed for breakfast?
Orange juice. And some toast.
SFX: Dispensing.
Thanks. Oh — some marmalade on that, please. And a pot of tea.

Your workshift starts at nine point five. TransAlliedInc is forbidden by law to insist you start before then, but reminds you that we're a happy corporation, full of happy employees, and it's perfectly normal if you want to get to work a little early.

Bit late for that, now. Tut tut, naughty Doctor. This is nice toast. Any chance of some more? And how about a grapefruit? EARPIECE And an extracaff coffee to perk you up and ready you for your working day?
No, no. This tea will be fine.
EARPIECE A suit has been provided for you, made to your measurements.
Very generous. But if I'm going to wear anything at
all, I'll wear my own clothes, thank you.
If you wish to mark yourself out as an individual, you have a choice of these four ties: single colour, striped, amusing cartoon animal, geometric design.
I don't want to wear a tie — wouldn't want the colours to clash with my coat, now, would I?
I will show you to your place of work. This way, Doctor.
SFX: Door. They're walking along. We get a sense of hubbub — this is a
vast open-plan office, with floors above and below all bustling with activity.
This Dome is very impressive. I'll want a full tour later.
Mr Baynes has it scheduled for ten point five. DOCTOR In here?
Your workshop is on the ninety-fifth floor. This lift will take you straight there.
SFX: Lift noises.
EARPIECE The share price is up another six points.
Don't you ever shut up?
I am here to provide you with all the information you need to be a happy, functioning employee of TransAlliedInc. In the absence of new information, I will play soothing music.
No thanks.
SFX: Door opens.
This is your workshop. Please be aware it is advisable to have an explanation for your lateness.
I'm barely two minutes late. It's not as though Davros I likely to punch in at nine-thirty sharp, is it?
SFX: Door.
Ah, Doctor, glad you could join us.
This is Arnold Baynes, the CEO of TransAlliedInc. This room is workshop 95A, the largest workshop in the Dome and —
(Over this) Excuse me a moment, Mr Baynes. Could you pass me that screwdriver?
Sure. Why do you need it?
I'm going to stick it in my ear.
It is fully-equipped with the latest electronic equipment (squeals, then stops).
Sorry about that, Mr Baynes. Now, when Davros gets here, I think I should —
There's no 'T' in 'team', Doctor.
I know how to spell —
Doctor.
Davros was here at seven this morning, keen to
started. He's already begun work on this positronic network. As you see, he's made a lot of progress.
Do not blame him, Mr Baynes — my life-support system means that, unlike the Doctor, I don't need to sleep.
The DOCTOR decides to brazen it out.

My Time Lord constitution means I don't need much sleep, either. An hour a night suffices. And I don't have to come to work a couple of hours early to get up to speed. I can see from here that you’ve configured the alpha matrix all wrong. Set it to three point seven.
SFX: Electronic tweaking, followed by a pleasant hum.
Remarkable. A threefold increase in neural activity.
It's nothing.
You have increased the risk of burn-out.
No, I wouldn't worry about —
SFX: A fizz, a pop — it sounds remarkably like a positronic brain
burning out.
Total burnout, on all circuits.
It's ruined!
Oh, dear. Back to square one, two and a half hours wasted — you could have stayed in bed, Davros.
You have deliberately destroyed my creation.
(This is a blatant lie) No. It was an accident. DAVROS An accident?
How was I to know that whoever designed the
network failed to build in adequate safety precautions? We'll start again, and this time /'// design the circuit.
How long will that take?
No more than an hour.
I'll be back then. Afterwards, I'll give you a tour of this Dome.
SFX: Door.
Davros, if you're not careful your face will stick like that. Now, could you pass me those neuronic pliers?
You sabotaged my work.
Sounds of electronic work going on.
No, no. Let's see... that's a good start. Could I have a clean screwdriver? Thank you. And that length of neural wire?
Baynes was clear, we are to work together.
We are working together. I'm pleasantly surprised just how well you're fitting in as my assistant. Now, I'm going to be a bit busy do you mind making me some tea?
(Growls)
Come on, Davros, making tea shouldn't be beyond you. After all, you can't say 'team' without saying 'tea’,
Cut to:
SCENE 2.3 - COMPUTER ROOM.
SFX: Computers chattering away — this is a small room. Door.
— Howis Davros?
He seems fine. It's the Doctor I'm worried about. He's acting like a child — but I think Davros is right, he's up to something. Computer noises.
_ Well, I've been digging up some notes on him. None
of my sources can offer much insight though. There are dozens of fleeting references — hundreds — but nothing substantial.
Keep looking.
__ Iwas hoping to start interviewing Davros today.
You can do — but I need your research skills to find
out about the Doctor first.
— Youare worried by him.
Yes.
~ Well, why don’t simply have him... removed?
Well, we don’t know very much about the Doctor, but
we know what he does to is enemies. I'd rather we kept him close. Talking of enemies... I've got an interview with that journalist, Willis.
_ He’s an enemy?
Well, I don’t know his news service, so he's near enough.
— Who does own it?
It's one of the independents.
Ah.
Exactly. He’s an asteroid-hugging halfwit. But no
publicity is bad publicity. And it’s always funny to hear them bleating on. By definition, they don't understand how the galaxy works.
_ By definition?
Yes. If they knew how the galaxy really works, they'd know that it's because of people like me, not despite of it. I'm the solution, not the problem.
Cut to:
SCENE 2.4 —- WORKSHOP.
What are you doing here, Doctor?
Helping to make a better world, Davros, just like that nice advert said. This new alpha matrix is coming along nicely.
You want to see me destroyed.
I don't want you to destroy all other life in the galaxy
— there a precedent for suspecting there is a distinction. And there’s something of a precedent for suspecting that’s what you’re up to.
I am alone, Doctor. The last of my race.
Only because you were instrument a in their
extermination.
Indeed. Doctor, do you know who is the nearest thing that I have to a friend?
No.
You.
Me? But —
We have been through a lot together, have we not?
We are both scientists. Your intellect, your experience — you are a shining light in a dark galaxy. We have much m common.
We're not friends, Davros.
No. No, but I often think that in some strange dream of history we could have been. Fate has made us allies — imagine what we could achieve.
You're dangerous.
All men of destiny are.
Men of what? Destiny? I'm a time traveler, Davros — perhaps I have a different perspective on fate and destiny.
Perhaps you have. But you’re one of the elite. A Time
Lord not one of the rabble. I think Baynes and his wife are like us. We can achieve great things.
You can’t have four supreme beings, Davros, by definition.
I always thought it was a question of destruction — but
I see now that the constant fighting just cancels out any gains. If we can work together...
DOCTOR To what end? I know you of old, Davros. I know your nature.
DAVROS The human race has abandoned the death penalty.
(Wary at the change of subject) Yes.
Why?
Because humans hold life to be sacred. Because they
believe that even the worst criminal might be rehabilitated.
Precisely.
You think you're a reformed character?
Not yet. But I have been given a new chance. I intend to take it.
DOCTOR The humans have a saying — 'A Dalek can't change its
bumps.’
I am not a Dalek. I have always been in control of my destiny, Doctor. I have misused that power. Done terrible things.
But now you're going straight?
I understand your scepticism. All I ask is that you judge me by my actions.
Don't worry, I'll be right here, doing just that. Fade to:
SCENE 2.5 — DOME OFFICE.
So, Mr Willis, ask me anything.
I'll just get the recorder going. There. So. Arnold Baynes, s the head of TAI, what do you think your greatest responsibility is?
My greatest responsibility? Well, I'd say that it's identifying what the people of this galaxy want, before they know they want it.
Before they know?

Developing a new technology, researching the market for it, testing it, getting it to comply with all the laws and local customs and restrictions. That alone takes several years. If we want to give people what they want, right now, then we would have had to anticipate the demand years ago.
But how much of that is telling people they want?
I don't understand.
Well, you offer these products. What if people really want something completely different which you're not offering?
We're not the only corporation. And if we don't give our customers what they want, someone else will.
But many of the outer planets depend on TAI.
They choose TAI. There is a difference.
Only TAI ships go to some systems.
Because they're invited. Mr Willis, I think I've answered this question.
Okay. Davros. The announcement that you've hired Davros is bound to cause many people distress.
It's a bold move. We don't mean to distress anyone.
Almost everyone has a grandparent or great-
grandparent who was killed in the Dalek Wars.
Davros isn't a Dalek — his involvement with Dalek history is marginal.
(Flabbergasted) He created them.
He did but mere days later they killed him — or so it

was thought. It was thousands of years before he was revived, but again it was less than a day before he was captured by Earth forces and bought to trial. He can't be held responsible for what the Daleks did in the millennia in between.
You don't think he's culpable at all?
Davros is a scientist. You wouldn't blame Isaac Newton for the gravitronic bomb, or Faraday for the electric chair.
There will be many people who don’t see it that way.
Davros is perhaps the foremost single scientific

genius in the history of this galaxy. People may not like his past, but I'm guessing that when he solves the famine problems m the colonies, or develops a new totally efficient hyperdrive system, they won't refuse to use his technology.
What do you say to the anti-universalisation lobby, the people who say that corporations have too much influence?
I don't say anything at all to them. It’s kindergarten politics, not worthy of discussion. There are bigger projects.
You're committed to your workforce?
BAYNES Of course.
What about the rumours that you are planning to close your mining planets down?
Beat.
I haven't heard those rumours.
Are you saying you have no such plans?
This interview is terminated.
Sir, [-
Hand me that recorder.
No, I— hey!
SFX: BAYNES smashes the recorder.
What have you heard about the mines?
So, you do have —
Don't play games with me. Who's told you this?
I— are you threatening me, Mr Baynes?
You're on your own out here, Willis. You call for help, how long do you think it would be before anyone heard you? About a week.
I'm a member of the Galactic Press Association.
Spare me your 'ethics'. You've got a duty to report the truth. Not rumours and gossip.
WILLIS The truth as you see it.
BAYNES The truth is the truth. There's only one.
WILLIS The gospel according to TAI?
(Conciliatory) Mr Willis, we've got off on the wrong
foot. Now, if you'll just stick around for a few days, calm down a bit, then we'll conduct this interview again. I'll even get you a new voice recorder.
No. I want to leave.
As I say — stay here, calm down. We'll talk again.
I'm a prisoner?
Mr Willis, you've got alpha-grade access to the Dome.

That's a freedom that barely a hundred TAI employees have. You've got all the food you can eat, complete access to the datanet. If you're in prison, then so’s virtually the entire population of the galaxy. You think about that. Now, I've got work to do. Real work. Be seeing you.
The door slams shut, like a prison door. Cut to:
SCENE 2.6 —- WORKSHOP.
You don't understand, Doctor.
Understand what?
I spent ninety years alone with my thoughts after

humanity sentenced me to lifelong imprisonment. Many more years after that after my prison was destroyed, as I drifted in space. DOCTOR And now you've had a little think about it, you've decided to mend your ways?

DAVROS A little think? Ninety years. Do you have any idea? Your people are immortal, aren’t they? Ninety years to you must be nothing. For me it was a lifetime unable to move, I was in complete sensory deprivation. I wasn’t breathing, I couldn't even feel my heart beating. I sat utterly alone. I thought I would go insane.
No comment.

I wondered if I had died, after all. How would I know? I started hearing voices. I started imagining things out there in the darkness. Terrifying things, larger than me, all around me. It was like I had been cast adrift on a raft in the middle of the ocean. I heard the Daleks there, every one of them calling out my name in unison. They sounded so faint.
After your blood, or just demanding an apology for what you programmed them to do?

(Ignoring him) Then I saw your face, tormenting, sneering, cruel, cowardly, just as it is now, just as it has always been. Your true face, not the one you happen to be wearing today. Then there was nothing. A near-century of nothing. I turned inward. My mind consumed my memories, forced me to live and relive every single experience, from the moment I was born. Maybe even before that. I was locked in my past, unable to change my mistakes, condemned to relive them, over and over and over. Every death, every failure, every lie, every I betrayal. Even those I thought I had completely erased from my memory, like — (he stops)
Like?

Every one of the foul deeds I thought I had buried rose up. Taunted me. I felt so ashamed, so... naked. The process stripped me of everything. It showed me how small I was, how insignificant my achievements had been. I was nothing, the mere dreams of a man who should have died millennia before. I passed through eternity, imagining every possible theory, every possible book, every possible idea. And then, as I'd exhausted every combination, in that moment, I felt myself transcending. I felt myself starting to lift away from my body, to join with something greater than me, greater than all things. (Beat) And then I felt my heart beat. That had just been the first second of my imprisonment. And I was back at the beginning, utterly trapped, cursing those who had imprisoned me, a mere deformed, unfinished thing. Before the next heartbeat, the process was repeated in every detail. The third second was the same. As was the next. As was the next.
Well, as I'm only wearing a wristwatch, and I don't have a calendar on me, you should probably skip to the end.
DAVROS The end? Very well. I came to realise that I could count myself the king of an infinite universe, were it not for my bad
dreams. That there was more in heaven and Skaro than was dreamt of in my philosophy.
(Laughs) Eternity, and the best you could manage is to misquote Shakespeare? Any monkey with a typewriter could do the same — and at least they'd have managed to write something down.
My point precisely.
Good night, sweet prince — I'm off to get that cup of tea. This alpha matrix I've built is growing nicely — you keep your hand off it. (SFX: door) Ah, hello, Mr Baynes.
Are you two ready for lunch?
We can eat here.
Well, I'm afraid you can't. Galactic employment law requires you both to take at least a half-hour break.
You have laws that make your workers less productive?
People need rest.
Every four hours?
Davros, my wife has invited you to dine with her. She’s got our personal chef to come up with something.
Very well.
DOCTOR And I—?
There's the staff canteen. Before then, though, like to show you the computer centre —
Fade to:
SCENE 2.7 - COMPUTER CHAMBER. Hubbub. This is a large control room, full of people and equipment. The nerve centre of operations. BAYNES is in the middle of an introduction.
— the computer centre which coordinates all life here in the Dome. Everything from air conditioning to the production lines.
Very impressive. Absolutely everything runs from this centre? That would seem to make it vulnerable to attack.

They'd have to get through the walls of the Dome, first, and not even a battlecruiser could do that. Then the computer complex itself is built like a fortress, and is completely self-contained, With its own kitchens, communications centre, water supply — even an emergency medical centre.
I see.
This is one of our Delta-grade technicians, Kimberly Todd. Address any concerns to her. I just need to check some figures. Kim.
Hello.
Explain the operating principle of this processor to the Doctor. I'll be back in a moment.
(Whispers) Kim — where's Willis?
(Whispers) He's back in his quarters. He's had a run-in

with Baynes this morning. Doctor, we found a tunnel linking that secret hangar to the Dome. There's an elevator right here to the computer centre. It let us up, but it won't let us back down without the password.
Well, obviously Baynes likes to keep his secrets.
We also found an automated production line.
There are dozens of production lines here, aren't there?
Yes, but this one doesn't appear on any of the
databases. I checked that this morning.
Baynes just told me that everything was run through here.
That's what we are told. But I've double-checked — there's no hangar, that production line isn't showing up. If it was on this system, I'd. be able to find it.
DOCTOR And so what's he up to? Hang on — Baynes is coming back. (Loudly) I see — so that would explain why the K13 processor has been used, rather than the cheaper L4-11.
(Taken aback) That's right. I'm amazed you can tell just by looking at the casing.
Quality always demonstrates itself.
(Approaching) We always use the best, Doctor. We've got to resist the temptation to compromise.
Absolutely, absolutely. (Whispers to KIM) Kim, I'll meet you in your quarters ten minutes after the work shift ends.
I'll make sure Willis is there, too.
Cut to:
SCENE 2.8 — PRIVATE DINING ROOM.
Davros. Come in.
Mrs Baynes. It is you I have to thank for my recovery.
__ Yes. [have long been an admirer of yours. Here — take your place at the table.
You... admire me? I had understood that the human race reviled everything that I stood for.

__ Centuries have passed. Historians have returned to the subject of the Daleks with new perspectives. The old prejudices have been stripped away. We now appreciate there was much to admire about the Daleks and their creator.
DAVROS And everyone thinks like that?

_ No. Only a few of us carry the flame. But it burns bright. One day, the whole of humanity will see it that way. I have written books on the subjects — they are bestsellers. People want to hear the truth.
I... see. May I ask what the purpose of this meeting is?
_ Toeat. To talk.
I see. Your husband tells me there is no such thing as
a free lunch. So what is expected of me?

We know so little about you, but what we know is inspirational. In the entire history of this galaxy, there have been few to match you in the fields of leadership, science, ambition. And to do that from such a world as Skaro...
It was the only world I knew.
We humans don't have much information about Skaro — few who have been there have ever returned. I have some photographs. Here.
How were these obtained?
__ A robot probe took these photos and managed to transmit them before it was detected and destroyed.
I have never seen the planet from space before.
— One of your fields of research was rocketry.
Yes, but I built rockets to fire at the Thals, not at the moons.
Here. Falkus and Omega Mysterium. The moons of Skaro. You must have seen them?
Yes. When I was young. Before shelters. Before —
He hesitates. LORRAINE breaks the silence.
_ Before?
It doesn't matter. That is my past. Skaro is my past. Here, takes these back.

_ ['mahistorian, Davros. My interest is in the past. You past in particular. You have correctly guessed that I have an ulterior motive — I want to write the definitive biography of Davros, the greatest individual this galaxy has ever produced.
I see.
— And what better way than to interview you? To hear about your past in your own words.
I have much to offer in the present.
LORRAINE Of course. No one doubts that. But are all shaped by our past, aren't we? And we know so little of yours.
I see.
—_ You sound disappointed.
No. Just surprised. I confess that I am a little out of
my depth in this world. It seems strange to me. This meal is...
He struggles for the word.
__Itis to your liking? If not, I will have replaced and —
Yes. Of course. I am sure it is good. There is justt so much. My life-support systems are very efficient, I don't need to eat that often. And I lack teeth. And taste buds.
— You must miss good food.
DAVROS On Skaro, even before my accident, we only had food pills.
_ The overpopulated colony planets have food pills. Famine is a serious problem in much of the galaxy.
Overpopulation was never a problem on Skaro.
_ But you've only eaten pills before?
DAVROS From time to time, another opportunity presented itself.
Fade to:
SCENE 2.9 -SKARO WASTELAND.
SFX: Constant distant shelling. This is broken ground — every move
disturbs a pile of rubble.
(Unmodulated) Wait.
Davros, what is it?
SFX: Skittering in the rubble.
There. A rodent. One of the herbivorous ones. We should catch it.
Why? We can't eat it. The radiation levels out here are will over safety levels.
It's alive. That's healthy enough for me.
What's wrong with food pills?
You know where they come from?
Packets.
Before then. Wait (Beat) Got you!
SFX: But there's clattering and skittering and the little animal gets
away.
(Laughs)
I will capture it.
Wait a moment. Where do food pills come from?
Where do you think?
This is one of your scientific tests, isn't it? Well...
before war, people used to eat plants and special food animals.
Cattle.
Is that what the word used to mean? I've only heard it to mean Thal prisoners.
But cattle need to eat plants.
Inefficient. We should just eat the plants ourselves. DAVROS And that's what we’d did. But plants need sunlight to grow.
There’s been no sunlight since the atomic shelling began.
No.
So how do the plants grow?

BAYNES: That's all there is, Lorraine. The human race
BAYNES: consuming and expanding.
LORRAINE: — You make us sound like locusts.
BAYNES: No. Far more efficient than that, far more driven. There are more galaxies than there are grains of sand on a beach. There is so much more. And Davros will help us make the leap to other
BAYNES: galaxies.
LORRAINE: ~ What if he doesn't want that?
BAYNES: We're kindred spirits. I can sense it. He and [ are...
BAYNES: we're the same. Driven, ambitious, radical — maybe even a little bit ruthless. In the end, though — well, he's a research scientist. How
BAYNES: dangerous can a jumped-up lab technician be?
LORRAINE: — Youare both men of destiny, Arnold. The sort of people that history bends to accommodate.
LORRAINE: BAYNES And you?
LORRAINE: __ I'msomeone that can see the course of history. Someone that knows that we're on the verge of forging a new era.
LORRAINE: SCENE 3.11 - BEDROOM.
DAVROS: Mr Willis, you have serious reservations about the economic system?
WILLIS: Er, yes.
DAVROS: I would be interested to hear what those reservations are.
WILLIS: You would?
DAVROS: Yes. Mr Baynes is clearly one of the lucky ones. Yet there are citizens of other planets dying from diseases?
WILLIS: That's right.
DAVROS: Diseases which human scientists have cured?
WILLIS: Not everyone can afford the drugs. People like Baynes
WILLIS: would say that the galaxy is overpopulated anyway, it's good if there's something that eases that pressure.
DAVROS: Baynes has said that?
WILLIS: No. Well, he might have done. I don't know.
DAVROS: He wouldn't say that if it was his life at risk, would he?
WILLIS: No, sir. Davros... there are millions like me. People
WILLIS: who hate the corporations, who think they are synonymous with greed. They've destroyed whole planets, stripped them bare. And for what? Just to fuel more growth, to generate more money.
WILLIS: DAVROS The economic system of the galaxy is fundamentally flawed. The corporations could be a force for good, but they are compelled to fight one another.
WILLIS: We've tried to highlight all that in our news service. But no one has ever come up with a better system.
DAVROS: I'm sure they have. But the corporations have bought
DAVROS: them off. Or had them killed. That is what absolute rulers do.
WILLIS: Changing the economy of the whole galaxy just
WILLIS: couldn’t happen. There have been scandals and crises, but the corporations always survive — or new ones take their place.
DAVROS: Are all the people that think like you such defeatists?
WILLIS: We can't beat the corporations. They control everything, employ everyone.
DAVROS: I have the means to destroy them. Once and for all.
WILLIS: You do?
DAVROS: You understand how the stock market functions?
WILLIS: Well... sort of. The basics.
DAVROS: Explain them.
WILLIS: Well, people with money invest that money in
WILLIS: companies that they think will do well. People take risks, sometimes they rewarded, sometimes they are ruined.
DAVROS: But it is the element of risk that's important?
WILLIS: Well, yes. My father always said it was like horse racing: gambling, but with people's lives.
DAVROS: Yes. And if you knew the outcome of each race
DAVROS: beforehand, would it be gambling? (Beat) I can predict the stock market.
WILLIS: You can?
WILLIS: DAVROS With one equation. I have now checked the records for the last five hundred years. The formula holds. I can predict the price of any stock at any time, anywhere.
WILLIS: That power would set me up for life. You. It would make you rich. More than rich.
DAVROS: If I was the only person to have the equation. WILLIS Of course. I mean, you wouldn't share it, would you?
DAVROS: Why not?
WILLIS: Because if everyone had the equation, then the whole system... would... collapse.
DAVROS: Precisely.
WILLIS: (Realising) You can do it.
DAVROS: I will do it. But Ineed your help. This disk contains
DAVROS: the equation, how the equation was devised, and a simple program that will run on even a household computer. Your job is to disseminate information — your news channel will run the equation.
WILLIS: But there will be chaos.
DAVROS: No. There will be a new order. A new economic
DAVROS: model have designed for the galaxy. I alone will be prepared for the collapse the corporations. I will be able to use the TAI infrastructure to impose the new system.
WILLIS: I imagine it would have to based on a loose, grass- roots system. A network of communes, committed to the environment of each world. Self-sufficient planets, but bartering goods if they have a surplus.
DAVROS: I have been searching Mrs Baynes' history books to see if there is a precedent for what I am doing.
WILLIS: Not on this scale. The main problem will be re-
WILLIS: education — the human race has got so used to commerce, that a switch to the post-economic system, where people only take what they need will be difficult to adjust to.
DAVROS: Essentially, the entire galactic economy will switch to a war footing. Criminals and undesirables will be put to work as labourers, those with particular aptitudes will form the elite, and will be granted limited rights. Those in the middle, the citizens, will provide a workforce. The women will produce and rear children, the men will work in new factories and in the armies, and all surplus production capacity will go into armaments —
WILLIS: What? No! I won't be — hell... this damn door won't open for me. Let me out!
DAVROS: Willis, you are intelligent and resourceful and I had
DAVROS: hoped you would be in my new elite — subversives and troublemakers will suffer a rather different fate. Please don't disappoint me.
WILLIS: Let me out!
DAVROS: As you wish. (SFX: Door) But please think about my offer.
DAVROS: Cut to:
DAVROS: SCENE 3.12 - WORKSHOP.
DAVROS: Door.
BAYNES: Doctor, hasn't Davros arrived yet?

WILLIS: BAYNES A resourceful young man. I thought I had him under control.

BAYNES: Then let's go and see him. Get him out of the way. Cut to:
BAYNES: SCENE 3.13 -DOME/COMPUTER CHAMBER. Lift going up. KIM is humming. Chime and the lift slows and then the doors open. KIM's humming stops as she sees who it is.
DAVROS: Good day.
KIM: (Nervous) Hello. How can I help you?
DAVROS: You are taking this lift to go to the computer centre?
KIM: Yes. I'm a technician there.
DAVROS: I will accompany you. If that is agreeable.
KIM: Er... yes. Of course. My name is Kim. Kim Todd.
KIM: Lift operates.
DAVROS: I am Davros. How long have you worked at the computer centre, Miss Todd?
KIM: Five years.
DAVROS: Excellent. I have a project that requires me to upload files to the galactic datanet.
KIM: I don't have that authority.
DAVROS: If I had, would you be able to operate the communications terminal?
KIM: Only Mr Baynes has that authority. We need tight security to prevent company secrets from being leaked.
DAVROS: That was not my question.
KIM: I have often helped Mr Baynes transmit files, yes. Door opens.
DAVROS: Excellent. We appear to have arrived. Proceed. I will meet with you in a minute or so — I have business to attend to first.
KIM: As you wish, Mister Davros.
LORRAINE: Davros.
DAVROS: Ah, Mrs Baynes. Good to see you again.
LORRAINE: — (To DAVROS) My husband has been looking for you. You weren't in the workshop or with me. I thought you'd be heading here.
LORRAINE: DAVROS An excellent deduction.
LORRAINE: __ The way you were looking at that technician...
DAVROS: She reminds me of somebody.
LORRAINE: _— Shan?
DAVROS: How...?
LORRAINE: You mentioned her name before. So, who was she? Cut to:
LORRAINE: SCENE 3.14 —- KALED CITY.
SHAN: Coordinator Davros, I am Shan.
DAVROS: Ah, yes, the latest recruit to Science Division. You are the same Shan who wrote a paper on the long-term effects of the atomic shelling?
SHAN: That is right. You read that?
DAVROS: I read every paper. (Beat) But that one was one of the
DAVROS: few to impress me.
SHAN: If the war continues much longer, the entire biosphere will be devastated.
SHAN: DAVROS The Kaleds did not start the shelling.
SHAN: Sir, it doesn't matter who drops the bombs, the poisons still enter the earth and the water supplies.
DAVROS: Indeed.
DAVROS: SHAN The Kaleds will win the war, but we could be left with a dead planet.
DAVROS: DAVROS The inevitability of science
SHAN: Nothing is inevitable, Davros. We shape our own destiny.
DAVROS: That is not what your paper says.
SHAN: My paper ends with a number of suggestions that —
DAVROS: Shan, I know how your paper ends. A couple of
DAVROS: piecemeal fixes that might just have some effect. But we both know what your real conclusion is.
SHAN: Yes, sir. We have to adapt or die.
DAVROS: We?
SHAN: Life.
DAVROS: Kaled and Thal?
SHAN: I think we have gone beyond that.
DAVROS: Yes. Do you think that is why the two races are trying to kill each other?
SHAN: Sir?
DAVROS: Do you think we know deep down that this is a
DAVROS: suicidal war, whatever our political officers tell us? That every death just puts people out of their misery?
SHAN: Sir, I believe there is a way to survive this.
DAVROS: No.
DAVROS: SHAN With respect, Coordinator: yes. I have prepared a new paper. One that proposes a solution.
DAVROS: DAVROS An end to the war?
SHAN: Not necessarily.
DAVROS: I am a scientist, Shan. I spend most of my time
DAVROS: developing weapons. But over the years I have given a great deal of thought to more radical solutions. It is clear to me that the only hope for the Kaleds is to cooperate with the Thals.
SHAN: We are two different races in the same ecological niche, sir. Every biologwal imperative makes cooperation impossible. The Kaleds must destroy the Thal species for the sake of our own.
DAVROS: Then your solution is some devastating weapon? Something even I have not conceived of?
SHAN: No, sir. More radical than that.
DAVROS: Tell me.
SHAN: We are approaching the problem from the wrong angle.
SHAN: DAVROS The problem is simple: prolonging the war will mean
SHAN: that soon this world will not be able to support Kaled life. We lack the ability to leave this world — there are no other worlds that would support life in any case. The only solution is to end the fighting. And we cannot do that because our enemies will destroy us. Either way, the Kaled race is dead.
SHAN: Yes. I agree with all of that.
DAVROS: Yet you have a solution?
SHAN: Yes.
DAVROS: Tell me.
SHAN: Read my new paper, sir.
DAVROS: Does it have a title?
SHAN: Yes sir. (Beat) I call it 'The Dalek Solution’ . DAVROS And this word... 'Dalek'. What does it mean? SHAN To discover that, sir, you will have to read the paper. Cut to:
SHAN: SCENE 3.15 - COMPUTER ROOM.
LORRAINE: _ So... you didn't create the Daleks?
DAVROS: I created them. She proposed the idea, but I was the
DAVROS: one that experimented on Kaled embryos. I told them the chemicals I
DAVROS: was injecting them with would make their babies stronger. I didn't tell them that it would also make them change species.
LORRAINE: You must have felt...
DAVROS: Yes?
LORRAINE: _ Idon't know. Guilt? Pride? Horror? I honestly don't
LORRAINE: know. You were making a monumental decision, but —
DAVROS: I felt nothing.
LORRAINE: — You must have felt —
LORRAINE: with a Dalek mutant's hissing instead of crying.
DAVROS: I remember the first birth. The first live birth. The mother felt pride and anxiety. Have you got children, Mrs Baynes?
LORRAINE: No.
DAVROS: I imagine that what unites the humans, the Kaleds and the Thals is pride in the birth of a new child. The hope, the fear that something will go wrong. Nothing went wrong, as far as I was concerned. But —
DAVROS: DAVROS The mothers often felt differently. Those few that, survived the shock of childbirth.
LORRAINE: You were working to ensure the survival of life on your planet.
LORRAINE: DAVROS A creature that could breath air thick with mustard gas, drink poisoned water, eat the crops that grew in plutonium dust.
LORRAINE: _ A creature that could survive anywhere.
DAVROS: Yes.
LORRAINE: __ Those were your children.
DAVROS: Yes.
LORRAINE: This Shan. She was... she was one of the mothers?
DAVROS: No. What gave you that idea?
LORRAINE: __ [thought perhaps you and she were — ?
DAVROS: She was beautiful, Mrs Baynes. Young. Strong. A brilliant mind. The first mind I encountered that was more brilliant than my own.
LORRAINE: _ You loved her?
DAVROS: I am not sure that I have ever loved, Mrs Baynes. I am
DAVROS: not sure I have ever felt... anything.
LORRAINE: _ But you are one of the most driven beings there is. The daleks have extreme emotional —
DAVROS: I am not a Dalek. My life-support system perfectly regulates my body's functions. If I feel cold, it warms me. I feel hunger or tiredness, it neutralises them. At their root, all emotions are simple chemical responses. Fear, anger, jealousy. All can be regulated.
LORRAINE: _ But this was before your accident. Before you had your life-support system?
DAVROS: Yes. LORRAINE And still you felt nothing?
DAVROS: SCENE 3.16 — KALED CITY.
SHAN: Davros. You presented my paper to the Council.
DAVROS: Yes. As Coordinator, that was my duty.
SHAN: You didn't mention my name, though. You took all the credit.
DAVROS: You work under me. All scientific research needs my approval.
SHAN: You are a genius, Davros, there is no doubt about that.
SHAN: But this has always been my specialism. I understood that I would be the one to present to the Council on this matter.
DAVROS: It is a side issue.
SHAN: It is the fundamental issue, Davros.
SHAN: DAVROS The war is the only issue.
SHAN: We both know that isn't true. You read my paper. I was the only person thinking about what happens afterwards.
DAVROS: There won't be an afterwards. Not unless we win.
SHAN: Even if we win there will not be an ‘afterwards’.
SHAN: Already birth rates are falling, infant mortality is four times the level it was a generation ago.
SHAN: DAVROS The inevitable consequence of war. Who would want to bring children into this world now? The women don't want to be mothers any more, they want to help with the war effort.
SHAN: Are you telling me to shut up and start producing babies?
DAVROS: Shan...
SHAN: Is that all I... ?
DAVROS: No. You are a great scientist, Shan. Perhaps the greatest this planet will produce.
SHAN: Coordinator Davros, your own reputation is -
DAVROS: Shush.
SHAN: One day I may surpass you. But for now...
DAVROS: You are always thinking of the future, Shan. I admire that.
SHAN: Sir.
DAVROS: Your ideas are ahead of their time. I think only you and I truly understand the implications. Others, those less than ourselves, will be scared by what you propose.
SHAN: Sir, did you present all of my paper?
DAVROS: I removed certain of your conclusions. The Council do not need to know everything. Not yet. They are politicians. They would not approve the new experiments if they knew... what we know.
SHAN: That they are signing all our death warrants? That the new species will replace the original?
DAVROS: Yes.
DAVROS: Gut to:
DAVROS: SCENE 3.17 — MINES.
BAYNES: These tunnels go on forever, Doctor.
DOCTOR: This is a large complex, Baynes, but it's hardly infinite.
BAYNES: That shaft we just passed is over fifteen miles deep.
BAYNES: You fell down that, it would feel pretty infinite, believe me.
EARPIECE: Doctor — Willis is twenty metres straight ahead.
DOCTOR: Willis?
WILLIS: (Distance) Doctor? (Coming closer) Doctor, it's good to see you. You're the only one I can trust. Even Kim...
BAYNES: Kimberley Todd, the technician from the computer centre? She's in league with you, is she?
WILLIS: Doctor, you betrayed —
DOCTOR: He was in the room when you radioed me. And this
DOCTOR: man is the only person we have to convince about Davros.
WILLIS: But he's —

WILLIS: I know.
BAYNES: Not another one. Davros has a shady past, I suppose, but he's put that behind him. If either of you have evidence, could you just tell me what it is?
WILLIS: Davros is planning to destroy you.
BAYNES: He couldn't if he tried. I've got a few tricks up my sleeve you know. And trading accusations isn't evidence, Willis.
WILLIS: Not you personally — our whole economic system.
DOCTOR: He told you this?
